✶Good Evening Google+ ✶your daily story about art 09.28  2013
Tomorrow will be spent on the road home, so we shall celebrate the Birthday of Michelangelo Merisi, or Amerighi da Caravaggio, known generally as Caravaggio, who was born on September 28th in 1571 tonight.

Caravaggio has always been an artist who inspired (and titilated) the imagination
of art historians.   His short life, full of great and innovative are, religious paintings and a personal image as a truly 'bad boy', full of violence and an early death at only 38, not fully explained even today, all combine to make him one of the most interesting figures in Art History.

Caravaggio is best known for his religious paintings, showing figures from Biblical stories naturalistically as nomal, every-day people as well as for the dramatic lighting and perspective (foreshortening) in his paintings.  All of which can be observed in this painting, his Supper at Emmaus. 

The story of the painting is based on an episode in the Gospel of Luke, telling how a stranger sat down to eat with two of the Apostles in the town of Emmaus.  According to the Gospel, one of the Apostels was Cleophas, the other is un-named, but the shell on his tunic, sign of pilgrimage, has let art historians conclude that it must be Peter.  We see the story at the point of its highest drama, Christ has just blessed the Wine and the Bread, thus revealing himself to the two apostles before disappearing.

The shock of recognition of the two Apostles is clear, the one on the right throws out his arms as though emerging from the painting, while the other is making to rist from his chair, his elbow also seeming to poke at the canvas itself.  These elements of perspective, particularly the thrown out arm of the Apostle on the right, are called foreshortening and let the viewer see figures shown on the canvas as they would appear in real life, were the scene to take place before him or her.  Along with dramatic effects of lighting, as we see here in the shaft of light coming from the top left of the painting and the shadows, these are signature elements that Caravaggio introduced into art.

There are many other symbolic elements of Christian Art in this painting, from the apple, referring to the fall from paradise, to the the fruit on the table and the fish-like shadow thrown by the fruit basket, all of which re-inforce the elements of the Biblical story.  Which was quite intentional.  The painting, produced around 1601, fell into the height of the early Counter Reformation.  The Catholic Church was going all out to combat the influence of Luther's (heretical) Protestantism and had decreed in the Council of Trent that art should focus on showing understandable scenes, focusing on stories from the Bible and the mysteries of Christianity to strengthen the faith of the congregations.

In contrast to the more subtle and sophisticated paintings of many mannerist artists, Caravaggios naturalistic scenes, made more dramatic only by the effects of lighting and perspective, fulfilled these critera admirably, while still adding magnificent innovations to art.

Make your own way through the light and shadows of your day tomorrow, and tread lightly
